questions.question: What does the poet ask us not to crush?
questions.answer: A worm

questions.question: Who created the worm according to the poem?
questions.answer: God

questions.question: Which quality of the poet is shown in the poem?
questions.answer: Compassion

questions.question: Which celestial bodies are mentioned in the poem?
questions.answer: Sun, moon and stars

questions.question: What does the poet request us to respect?
questions.answer: All life

questions.question: Which figure of speech is used when the poet directly addresses the reader?
questions.answer: Apostrophe

questions.question: What does the phrase lowly bliss mean?
questions.answer: Simple joy

questions.question: What does the poet say we cannot give?
questions.answer: Life

questions.question: What lesson does the poem teach?
questions.answer: Respect for life

questions.question: Who wrote the poem The Worm?
questions.answer: Thomas Gisborne

questions.question: Who wrote the poem The Worm?
questions.answer: Thomas Gisborne

questions.question: Why does the poet appeal to us not to crush the worm?
questions.answer: Because even the worm is a creation of God and deserves life.

questions.question: What does the poet say about the creation of the worm?
questions.answer: He says it required God to form the worm.

questions.question: Which creations of God are mentioned?
questions.answer: The sun, moon, stars, and grassy earth are mentioned.

questions.question: What does the phrase thy being mean?
questions.answer: It means your life or existence.

questions.question: What does lowly bliss refer to?
questions.answer: It refers to the simple joy of small creatures.

questions.question: Why should we respect small creatures?
questions.answer: They too have life and a role in nature.

questions.question: What message is conveyed in the last line?
questions.answer: We should not take away life that we cannot give.

questions.question: Which figure of speech is used in Turn, turn thy hasty foot aside?
questions.answer: Apostrophe is used.

questions.question: What is the tone of the poem?
questions.answer: The tone is gentle and moral.

questions.question: What is the central theme of the poem?
questions.answer: Respect for all living beings.
